p:
The predicted average proportion of infected herds (Figure 3) was highly sensitive to the transmission rate due to P animals in the neighbourhood (
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\beta_{nb}^{P}$$\end{document}
β
nb
P
) (same behaviour for herd seroprevalence and herd incidence, data not shown). Indeed, this parameter had the largest sensitivity index both for the main and global effects, for all time-points of the outputs (Figure 3A). The second most influent parameter was surprisingly the transmission rate due to T animals within age-group (
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\beta_{w}^{T}$$\end{document}
β
w
T
), with one third of the global sensitivity due to interaction terms (Figure 3B), its effect being mainly potentiated by
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\beta_{nb}^{P}$$\end{document}
β
nb
P
(Additional file 1F, Figures S5 and S6). The sensitivity to variations in the neighbourhood radius
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$R_{nb}$$\end{document}
R
nb
, relatively small compared to the two first parameters, depended (positive correlation) on
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\beta_{nb}^{P}$$\end{document}
β
nb
P
(Additional file 1F, Figures S5 and S6). The impact of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$R_{nb}$$\end{document}
R
nb
was much less visible when varying it from 4 to 6 km, than from 2 to 4 km (Figure 3), due to a potential saturation effect since the number of neighbours was already large for
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$R_{nb} = 4km$$\end{document}
R
nb
= 4 k m
(50% of herds had more than 25 neighbours within this distance). The interactions of
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$R_{nb}$$\end{document}
R
nb
with the other parameters accounted for one third of its global influence on the average proportion of infected herds (Figure 3B).
